I understood that each of these questions were similar. Despite this, I felt I responded differently to each key word. For the word "lucky," I tended to see the 3 vs 18 section wheel as opposite extremes in terms of luck, where landing on the winning color on the 18 section wheel was essentially luck, whereas the 3 section wheel could have been slightly controlled by the torque of the spin by the user. I saw "barely" and "almost" questions in a more similar sense compared to "lucky," partially because the word "lucky" does not seem to be in the same categorical sphere as "barely" and "almost." More specifically, "lucky" seems to describe chance while "barely" and "almost" describe either user error or variability. Although, even for these two words, I answered in opposite sides of the scale for the 3 vs 18 section wheel due to the same reasoning above (probability).

Technically there is a 33.3% chance of winning each of them, so for the questions asking about how "lucky" the player was, I think of the player as being equally lucky on all of them. 1/3 is a pretty decent chance of winning, so I did not consider the player to be very lucky in any of the cases.  For the "barely" and "almost" questions, it is still pretty much the same thing - a 1/3 chance of winning. Although you might feel like you "barely" won or "almost" lost when the pin stops near the edge of the winning color, the odds are still the same. I varied my answers on these a little because of the feeling you get when the pin is near the edge.

For both barely and almost, I felt as if those were very weak statements because there is always a 1/3 chance of winning. If you win you win. If you lose you lose. There is no in-between. However, I could see some merit in luck because that person beat the odds against them.
